critique: This document pertains to the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933 and authorizes expenditures by heads of emergency agencies and executive departments using funds allocated by the President. It also ratifies expenditures made prior to the order. There is no direct indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, or social inclusion. The document expands executive power by granting broad discretion in fund allocation. It centralizes power at the federal level. It does not directly address national security or civil liberties. It involves government intervention in the economy through fund allocation. Therefore, the initial scores are: Ideological Tilt: 0, Immigration Approach: 0, Executive Power: 3, Federalism: 3, National Security vs. Civil Liberties: 0, Economic Regulation: 3, Social Inclusion: 0. Upon further reflection, the expansion of executive power is moderate, as it is tied to specific legislation. The federalism aspect is also moderate, as it relates to the allocation of funds within existing federal programs. The economic regulation aspect is also moderate, as it enables spending within the framework of the National Industrial Recovery Act.
